description: This is a very short hike that takes you to an old mining adit on the shore of the Walton River in Walton, Nova Scotia.Cross the old cemetery by the side of the road and then onto the salt march.  There is a small but deep brook to cross in the salt march towards the relatively high hill that stands between you and the Walton river.  There are a few mining adios that have been infilled on the eastern side of the hill.  However if you go around the hill to the side facing west and the Walton river, you come across a small adit that was used for mining.  It's about 30ft deep and 5ft high.  Just amazing to think that people used to spend days crouch in those to access minerals.  In front of the admit and towards the river, you will see a perfect circle of water (you can actually see this from google earth as well).  This is probably an old bend of the river that was cut off from the main channel some time ago.
directions: Highway 215 to Walton.  In Walton, turn on road going south(walton back Rd??).  this is the road that parallels the east side of the river.  Park by the church and cemetery on the right
title: Miner Brown Tunnel
